What's going on around town Thanksgivng weekend

Thanksgiving weekend isn't just for turkey in Louisville, so check out our events guide.

What's going on around town Thanksgivng weekend

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 10:23 a.m. EST November 25, 2014

Just about everything downtown will be decorated for Light Up Louisville, which kicks off Friday night.(Photo: Provided)

Story Highlights

  • Louisville has plenty of events throughout the long Thanksgiving weekend.
  • Light Up Louisville kicks off its 34th year on Friday with fireworks and Santa Claus.
  • The city's bar scene will be thriving with old friends reconnecting.
  • Lights Under Louisville is the world's largest underground lights display.
10 CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Thanksgiving might be the most socially fluid of all the major holidays. While Christmas comes with obligations that can't be easily dodged, many of them with full-blown guilt attached, Thanksgiving has a pronounced streak of nondenominational hedonism.

With ex-patriate Louisvillians in town for a four-day weekend, we thought a roundup of holiday-related destinations might be a good idea. Some are aimed at hanging with family, some with friends and, if you're lucky, a combination of both.

Happy Thanksgiving. Take the Bears and the points.

LIGHT UP LOUISVILLE

Light Up Louisville will turn four blocks of downtown Louisville into Christmas starting Friday, with two Christmas trees, tens of thousands of lights, fireworks, live music and Santa Claus.

The free event gets started with the extremely literal "Lots of Lights" parade at 6:30 p.m., leading up to Santa's arrival at 8. That's when he and Mayor Greg Fischer will throw the switch to light up Louisville, or at least the part of Fourth Street that stretches from Main Street to Muhammad Ali Boulevard.

RELATED: Light Up Louisville swag and giveaways Friday

Light Up Louisville kicks off 40 Nights of Lights, which will continue through Jan. 4 and include 250 animated snowflake and fleur de lis displays, LED arches above Fourth Street and 40 animated light-pole banners. Christmas trees will be at Fourth and Main streets and near Fourth and Liberty streets.

Much of it will be set to music, including the "Light Up Plaza" at Fourth and Jefferson streets, which will boast an elaborate 12-minute production every half hour starting at 6 p.m. A Lion Named Roar will perform at 7:30 and 8:30, including "Lights of Louisville," an original written for the event.

This is the 34th year that the city has celebrated the start of the winter holidays, and third since it expanded to 40 days and moved from Jefferson Square Park. Phil Miller, deputy director of communications for the mayor's office, said that Louisville has embraced the move and expansion.

"People like a community event," Miller said, "and they like that kind of collective moment where they can bring the family, people in from out of town, and just gather."

There will be two Zambelli fireworks shows, one Friday night after the lights go on and another Saturday at 8 p.m. Lights will be left on during the day, as per the public's request. Santa will take photos with children for free on Friday, and again on Dec. 6, 13 and 20 from 4 to 6 p.m. at the Louisville Visitor's Center for a $1 donation or canned good for Dare to Care.

A few events aren't technically part of 40 Nights of Lights, but strongly affiliated.

Christmas at the Galt House Hotel, one of Light Up Louisville's primary sponsors, will also offer a variety of events, most of which require a ticket. Returning will be an ice skating rink at 4th Street Live, using synthetic ice. It will be open seven days a week through Christmas Eve with hourly, daily and monthly rates.

Light Up Louisville is presented by Christmas at the Galt House Hotel, LG&E and Louisville: It's Possible Here. If you go, the official Twitter hashtag is #lightuplou.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Louisville-area shops offering Black Friday/Small Business Saturday deals

Lights Under Louisville. This is the only place on the planet where you can drive your car underground, through a giant cavern, and look at elaborate displays of Christmas lights. Legally, anyway.

The Louisville Mega Cavern, 1841 Taylor Ave., is currently filled with more than 850 displays comprised of more than 2 million points of light. Hours are 6-10 p.m. Thanksgiving Day and Friday and 5-10 Saturday and Sunday. Prices vary, but a car, truck, SUV or minivan is $25 per carload, payable only at the door. Or cave entrance. Whatever.

Thanksgiving Day at the Downs, 700 Central Ave. By now there's almost no chance you can get a ticket for Churchill Downs' famous Thanksgiving Dinner, which is nearly always a sell-out, but check www.churchilldowns.com just in case. Tickets are $26 and $60.

However, races will be run all day starting at 11:30 a.m. because, as we all know around here, jockeys aren't allowed simple pleasures such as eating a giant plate of food. There'll be 12 races, highlighted by the Falls City Handicap, and admission is $3.

Frazier History Museum, 829 W. Main St. The Frazier is bundling two holiday displays in "Irving Berlin's White Christmas, The Exhibit" and "Holidays Around the World." The second one is pretty self-explanatory, while the Berlin exhibit includes items from the late Rosemary Clooney's collection of memorabilia used in "White Christmas," the 1954 movie in which she co-starred with Bing Crosby and Danny Kaye. Prices vary, from $10.50 for adults to free for ages 4 and under, and hours are 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Friday and Saturday and noon to 5 Sunday.

COURIER-JOURNAL

5 reasons to shop local

NIGHTCLUBS

Nothing says Thanksgiving quite like ditching all of those relatives who, for all of the right reasons, you only see once a year. So let's take a look at the bar and nightclub scene.

Thanksgiving Eve at The New Vintage, 2126 S. Preston St., Scott Carney & Heavy Friends and Graffiti are teaming for a special show that may include any number of heavy friends stopping by (9 p.m., $10). And Thanksgiving night stars Philadelphia's Purling Hiss, a project led by singer and guitar hero Mike Polizze. Polizze has mastered a trash/underground/found music aesthetic that tends to explode in concert. Louisville's State Champion and Dad Bodies open (9, free).

COURIER-JOURNAL

Jeffrey Lee Puckett's 5 bands you'll want to see this week

On Thanksgivinig Eve at Headliners Music Hall, 1386 Lexington Road, 1386 Lexington Road, Ultra Pulverize will team with Wild and Woolly Video for a night of "Robocop" as the band performs a new score and the Night Vision DJs will play a late set (9 p.m., $10).

Gobblestock is back Thanksgiving night at The Phoenix Hill Tavern, 644 Baxter Ave., where Jefferson TARC Bus is reuniting (10 p.m., $10). At The Monkey Wrench, Johnny Berry & The Outliers will deliver their typically high-level honky tonk (10 p.m., $5).

The Young Widows wrap up a string of national shows with a Thanksgiving Eve show at Zanzabar, 2100 S. Preston St., including a few opening for Minus the Bear, with a hometown set of holiday favorites such as "Gift of Failure," "Doomed Moon" and "Old Skin." The Hot Wires open with songs from a new album, "Phantom Fire" (9 p.m., $10).

In Louisville, three bars tend to dominate the holiday conversation when it comes to reuniting with friends. A slightly older crowd gravitates toward the scenes of past crimes: The Back Door, 1250 Bardstown Road, The Outlook Inn, 916 Baxter Ave., and Gerstle's, 3801 Frankfort Ave., which will have Thumper & The Plaid Rabbits playing Saturday night.

This is obviously a small sampling, as Louisville is lousy with places to get a drink and tell high school stories. Just enjoy your weekend, stay away from ex-girlfriends and, above all, call a cab. They don't serve leftovers in jail.

Jeffrey Lee Puckett can be reached at (502) 582-4160, jpuckett@courier-journal.com and on Twitter, @JLeePuckett.
